metadata.case_name: Appellant (Mutawalli of Gholam Yahia Waqf Estate) v. State/Respondent No. 1

facts.text: Appellant was removed from his position as mutawalli of Gholam Yahia Waqf Estate on September 1, 1951, by an order passed by the Majlis constituted under the Bihar Waqfs Act, 1947.
Appellant appealed to the District Judge of Monghyr under the Act, and the operation of the removal order was stayed pending hearing of the appeal.

A complaint against appellant was filed on July 1, 1952, in the Court of the Sadar Sub-Divisional Magistrate, Patna, by Mohammad Sual, Nazir of the Majlis, alleging failure to prepare budget for year 1034 (1952-53) under s.58(1) of the Act and send copy to Majlis before January 15, 1952, committing offence under s.65(1). Office of Majlis at Patna.
Appellant tried by Munsif Magistrate Patna with First Class powers, convicted under s.65(1), sentenced to fine of Rs.100, in default 15 days simple imprisonment, on August 27, 1953.
Appeal to Sessions Judge, Patna, dismissed on November 23, 1953.
Criminal Revision No. 69 of 1954 in Patna High Court rejected on January 28, 1954.
Appellant obtained special leave to appeal against High Court order.
Found as fact that appellant failed to prepare budget of estimated income and expenditure of waqf estate and send copy to Majlis before January 15, 1952.

legal_issues.text: Whether the appellant's failure to comply with provisions of s.58(1) of the Bihar Waqfs Act, 1947 makes him liable to be punished under s.65(1).

Whether s.58 of the Act is invalid as it gives unrestricted power to Majlis to alter or modify budget without right of appeal, imposing unreasonable restriction on mutawalli's occupation under Art.19(1)(g) of the Constitution.
Whether Sessions Judge erred in placing onus on appellant under s.65(1) to prove reasonable cause.
Whether sentence of 15 days simple imprisonment in default of fine payment is valid under s.65 which provides only for fine.

petitioner_arguments.text: s.58 invalid because it gives unrestricted power to Majlis to alter or modify budget prepared by mutawalli without right of appeal, imposing unreasonable restriction on mutawalli in carrying on occupation, offending Art.19(1)(g).
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Art.19(1)(g) of Constitution; s.58 Bihar Waqfs Act

petitioner_arguments.text: Sessions Judge erred in placing onus on appellant under s.65(1) to prove reasonable cause for failure.
s.65 does not provide for imprisonment in default of payment of fine, yet sentenced to 15 days SI.
s.65 allows fine up to Rs.500 for second/subsequent offence (conceded this was first offence).

court_reasoning.text: s.58(1) requires mutawalli to prepare budget before Jan 15 each year and send copy forthwith to Majlis; failure punishable under s.65(1) with fine.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Clear from provisions that non-compliance with s.58(1) attracts punishment under s.65(1).

court_reasoning.text: Act for better administration of waqfs; Majlis has superintendence under s.27, mutawalli subordinate; s.58 reasonable restriction as budget indispensable, power to modify inherent in supervision; not unreasonable per Shirur Mutt; no unrestricted power due to s.58(6); even if sub-ss.(2)-(4) invalid, severable, obligation under (1) remains.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Provisions of s.58 reasonable restrictions, do not offend Constitution.

court_reasoning.text: Sessions Judge placed onus but also found prosecution proved failure on evidence apart from onus.
Sentence of imprisonment in default valid under s.33 CrPC read with ss.40,67 IPC.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Default imprisonment authorised by general criminal law.

holdings.text: Failure to comply with s.58(1) makes mutawalli punishable under s.65(1).
s.58 of Bihar Waqfs Act valid, imposes reasonable restrictions, does not violate Art.19(1)(g); even if parts severable, s.58(1) stands.
Onus point immaterial as prosecution proved case; default imprisonment valid.

precedents_cited.case_name: The Commissioner, Hindu Religious Endowments, Madras v. Sri Lakshmindra Thirtha Swamiar of Sri Shirur Mutt
precedents_cited.relevance: Budget indispensable in public institutions; not unreasonable to provide for preparation under supervision; power to alter inherent in supervision.

statutes_cited.name: Bihar Waqfs Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Imposes duty on mutawalli to prepare and submit budget; punishment for failure; Majlis superintendence and powers.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Claim of unreasonable restriction on occupation rejected.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Criminal Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Authorises imprisonment in default of fine.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code
statutes_cited.relevance: Read with CrPC s.33 for default sentence.

statutes_cited.name: Mussalman Wakf Act, 1923
statutes_cited.relevance: Previous law for waqf administration, accounts, punishment; similar purpose.

outcome.summary: The appeal is dismissed. The conviction under s.65(1) of the Bihar Waqfs Act for failure to submit budget under s.58(1) and sentence of Rs.100 fine or 15 days SI in default upheld. s.58 held valid and reasonable.

key_quotes.text: "It is clear from the provisions of s. 58(1) that before January 15, each year, the mutawalli of each waqf shall prepare a budget for the next succeeding financial year and shall forthwith send a copy thereof to the Majlis. Under s. 65(1), if he fails to comply with the above, he is liable to be punished with fine."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Directly interprets statutory obligation and penalty.

key_quotes.text: "Having regard to the fact that the mutawalli occupied the position of a manager or a custodian and that some kind of control or supervision over him by the Majlis with respect to due administration of the waqf property and due appropriation of funds was certainly necessary, we are of the opinion that the provisions of s. 58 of the Act are reasonable restrictions."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "a budget is indispensable in all public institutions and that it is not per se unreasonable to provide for the budget of a religious institution being prepared under the supervision of the Commissioner or the Area Committee."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Relies on Shirur Mutt to affirm reasonableness of budget supervision.
